The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
The boy sat there on the worn couch, a sixteen-year-old ghost in the dim light. His friend had eased him in, spoken of troubles at home, of parents who wielded a hammer instead of a touch.  The next day, news came. The boy had called the law. I drove out to the house, a wisp of a hope stirring in my chest. A psychology degree, I thought, maybe that could help. I spoke to the law, spoke to the parents, their faces tight with a kind of practiced fear. "Manipulative," they called him, their words thin and brittle.  He was a boy trying to breathe, and they were choking him. That's when it became clear.  Social work. This was the path. 

There's a hollowness in a society that claims to value the individual while churning them out in identical molds.  We mourn the broken, yet we celebrate conformity. I've never been one for fitting in.  From the unnatural hues in my hair to the piercings that defied convention, from the quiet stand against injustice to the fight for those silenced, I've always sought to carve my own space. This is the heart of social justice, isn't it? To see the person, the beating heart beneath the societal expectations, and fight for their right to exist. It's a fight I've waged my whole life, and it's a fight I intend to continue.

The paper concerns itself with the twin shadows of insomnia, the biological and sociocultural. The biological leans towards the hardwired, the genes inherited, the body's mechanics. It seeks the source of sleeplessness in the very marrow. The sociocultural, it casts a wider net, examining the world's pull on the mind, the threads woven through race, class, and circumstance. This review seeks to unravel both these threads, to trace the paths of research that illuminate these models, to weigh their findings against the anvil of reality. 

Sleeplessness takes many forms. Primary, where the roots lie solely within the self. Dyssomnias, the disorders of sleep itself, where the body rebels against its call. Or Parasomnias, where the sleep landscape is twisted, dreams bleeding into waking hours. Then there are the disorders born of other ailments, mental or physical, or the poison of substance. Primary Insomnia, the inability to find rest, Primary Hypersomnia, the weight of endless slumber. Narcolepsy, the thief of control, stealing the body's strength, leaving it trembling in the wake of sleep's embrace.  

The biological model whispers of neurons, of the hypothalamus, the orexin, the conductor of sleep and wakefulness. This study, it delves into the brains of mice, their GABAB receptors, keys that unlock the gates of slumber. A flick of the switch, a manipulation of these receptors, and sleep emerges, a tide receding and returning. 

But the question remains: can we extrapolate these findings to the human condition? Is this mouse a mirror held to our own souls? If so, what does it tell us?  A flaw in this receptor, a genetic quirk, could leave a man adrift in a sea of sleepless nights. And the sociocultural echoes? If this predisposition is inherited, it paints a grim picture. A child born into a world where sleep eludes them, a burden passed down through generations, hindering their every waking moment. School, work, the mundane tasks of life, all become poisoned by sleeplessness, a constant struggle against the tide.

The paper leans into three reckonings of what they call Central Auditory Processing Disorder, CAPD. 

First, a sketch of the thing itself. Then, the ways of knowing if it's there, the telltale signs. And finally, how a teacher in a room full of sound might help a child who bears this weight.

CAPD, or APD, they say it's a matter of how the mind makes sense of what the ears hear. The brain, the central nervous system, can't quite do its job right. The sound gets there, clear enough, but the switching, the sorting, the making of meaning, it falters. The ears ain't the problem, it's what comes after. The soul of the hearing, they say. 

They first whispered about this in the fifties, 'auditory imperception' was the name then.  Kids with troubles speaking, they thought something was amiss. Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari, testing the children in Italy. Kimura, in '61, spoke of dichotic testing, the way the brain splits the sound world.  A conference in '77, a gathering of minds, and the talk turned to this thing, this CAPD.

The signs, they come in many forms. Sound, it may not be heard right, lost in the spaces between. Words, they may blend together, indistinguishable. Patterns, unseen. Sarcasm, a change in tone, lost on the ear. One sound buries the next.  The mind, it can't weave the threads of sound into a tapestry of meaning.

To find it, they observe, they test.  Audiologists, speech therapists, psychologists, they all have their tools. Questionnaires, observations, sounds presented and responses measured. No single test, no surefire sign. The cause, a mystery.  Some tests, they bombard the ears with noise, see if the mind can pick out the signal. Others, they measure the echoes within the ear, the brain's own whispers.

The play, Twelfth Night. It speaks to the nature of disguise, how it can serve a purpose, a dark purpose, but how in the end it eats away at a man, a woman, a soul. To shed the mask, to reveal the face beneath, that is a risk. A risk of exile, of being cast out by those who knew you only in the shadows. 

The question then becomes one of choice. To preserve the self, or the fragile threads of connection that bind us to others. Some will turn away from the truth, others will bear it like a wound. And the deception of gender, that is a wound that cuts deep. Why would anyone seek to become another? To hide in the skin of the opposite? That is the question Viola wrestles with, driven by a need for survival.  "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…" she says. A foreign land, a perilous journey, and the weight of her own identity cast off like a discarded coat. But the disguise takes hold, alienating her from her own kind, severing the bonds of sisterhood. 

And then there is the confusion, the tangled web of desire. Olivia, caught in the snare of Viola's fabricated masculinity, falls for the phantom, calling her "husband." Orsino, the Duke, consumed by his own melancholia, finds himself drawn to the charade, confessing his love for the boy Cesario. "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me." 

This play, it speaks of hidden desires, unveiled by the artifice. Does Olivia truly yearn for men, or does she mistake the mask for the man? Or is it a mockery of her own society, a reflection of their shallow judgments?  The truth lies somewhere in the shadows, obscured by the play's own ambiguity. Olivia, she moves from Cesario to Sebastian with a swiftness that suggests a heart easily swayed. And Viola, stripped of her disguise, is embraced as a sister, not a lover. The mask removed, the truth revealed. But at what cost?

The shadow of empire fell heavy on the land. German, they called it. Brutality, a word whispered in the dust, etched in the bones of the Ovaherero, the Nama. Genocide, a stain on the sun-bleached plains of South West Africa. But empire, like the land itself, was a vast and varied thing. Policies, like the shifting sands, flowed in different currents.  Education, too, wore many faces.  East Africa, Tanganyika, taken by the British under a different sky, held a people literate, educated, their minds touched by the German hand.  Kamerun, too, bore witness to such endeavors.

But South West Africa, a land of stark contrasts, held a different story.  Here, the state, the iron fist of government, did not reach out to the native.  The task of instruction, of shaping young minds, fell to the missionaries, their churches echoing with hymns and prayers, their schools a refuge, a lifeline.  Limited, meager, the government’s support. Yet, the Europeans, the settlers who carved their names on the landscape, they were different.  State schools rose for them, their education nurtured, their futures assured.

The legacy of these policies, like the ghosts of the past, lingered. While East Africa boasted a literate citizenry, South West Africa remained cloaked in ignorance.  A vast majority, untouched, uneducated, their words lost in the wind.  What forces, what unseen hands, shaped this divergence? This paper seeks to delve into the hearts of the settlers, into the minds of the authorities, to uncover the reasons, the justifications, the justifications…

The books speak of this, written in tongues of German and English, their pages filled with narratives of education, of systems, of comparisons.  Cohen, a scholar, a seeker of truth, he wrote of South West Africa, of East Africa, drawing parallels, illuminating the differences.  He saw in the settler population, the driving force behind the divide.  

South West Africa, a land of temperate climes, a land where even the desert held a certain beauty, it attracted the Europeans.  In 1913, nearly fifteen thousand of them walked its soil, more than any other colony save East Africa.

Popular music, a sprawling, tangled thing, has grown beyond counting in these last hundred years. Genres, like roots spreading, creep and intertwine. The names alone - rap, rock, country, jazz, folk - whisper of a multitude. And within each, a thicket of subgenres, deeper still, branching out like veins in a corpse. Heavy metal, that brooding child of rock, has become a world unto itself in the last four decades. A world of noise and fury, expressing the dark corners of the soul. It ain't pretty, but it's honest. Diversified, too. Bands took the raw materials, twisted and turned them, birthing subgenres that spawned sub-subgenres, and so on, a fractal of sound echoing out into the night.

Now, the metal beast has grown so vast, so many heads, it's hard to say what it truly is. It's absorbed threads from every other genre, a chameleon of sound. But every beast has a genesis. To understand the metal that bleeds out of every speaker, you gotta dig down, find that first spark. Metal ain't just a genre. It's a movement, a force of nature.

Darkness is its creed. More bass, more volume, more violence. Less innocence, more goddamn skill. Metal musicians, they know their instruments like they know their own bones. And like a fever dream, it's fueled by the haze. The psychedelic boom of the seventies, it turned minds to acid, spewing forth music that was wild and strange. It was a soundtrack to the apocalypse, a reflection of the world fracturing around them. Visceral, raw, honest. Something new in a world of polished pop. And the ghosts of Romanticism, they whisper in the shadows, their darkness echoing through the decades. 

Lyrics like these, they speak to the heart of it:

*Helter Skelter*

The Beatles, they  wrote it, a glimpse into the darkness that lurked beneath the surface. A spiral, a descent, the highs and lows of a drug-fueled journey. Some say it's the first metal song, a challenge to the Stones, a declaration of their own darkness.

The Surrealists, they came along later, with their strange visions of dreamscapes. But before them, there was Rousseau, painting his own dreams, real as the brushstrokes themselves. The Dream, 1910, a canvas thick with his longing. Not just a woman lost in wonder, but Rousseau’s own heart laid bare. He dreamed of being seen, of the brushstrokes earning their keep, of the whispers in polite art circles. But the world, it was a hard place. To be accepted, to be deemed worthy, did he have to mimic the ghosts of masters past? Or carve his own path, a lonely road under an unforgiving sun?

The Dream, it holds the answer, or at least a piece of it. To understand it, you gotta know his story. Born in Laval, a small town in the north, to a tinsmith with a taste for comfort. No schooling in the fine arts, just the toll booths and the dust of the road, a gabelou, they called him. Douanier, the customs man, a name he wore like a borrowed coat.  His first wife, Clémence, vanished with eight children, leaving him with a daughter, Julia, and a grief that tasted like ash. Painting, it became his refuge, his way to stitch together the torn edges of his soul.

He wasn't like the other painters, those who romanticized the peasant life. Rousseau was the peasant, his canvas a reflection of their hopes and dreams. 

He hungered for acceptance, and no wonder. He started late, with no guidance, a voice crying out in a wilderness of talent. Matisse, he was already making a name, while Rousseau toiled in the shadows. To be admitted to the Artiste Français, he thought, he had to paint what they wanted, what was expected.

“Matisse, he feared the ordinary,” wrote Jan Gordon, a chronicler of the age, “but Rousseau yearned for it, for a way in.”

The notion of a kinship 'tween ethics and aesthetics, truth and beauty, has been pondered by many a thinker. A reason, I believe, lies at the heart of it. As Keats writes, "Beauty is truth, truth beauty—That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know." Much of what we grasp in this life comes from the books we read or the roads we walk. Yet, ethics and aesthetics, like Keats suggests, seem to take root in us without the hand of instruction. Both are more a matter of describing than dictating. Our study of right and wrong, of beauty, is largely an attempt to unravel the why—why a canvas sings, why an act aligns with the moral compass. Not a rulebook for judgment or creation, mind you.

Criticism, be it of art or morals, can never fully grasp the essence of what's good or what's beautiful. Talk of da Vinci's Mona Lisa might delve into foreground, background, contrast, the weight of history. But these things, they don't tell the whole story. When asked about a cherished work, a piece of writing that lingers, you'll often hear, "There's just something about it," before the words stumble to explain. Art and morals, I reckon, they can't be fully pinned down. As Flannery O'Connor said, "A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way ... you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate." No matter how sharp the description, something transcendent remains. Ethics, I believe, has this same quality. Wittgenstein, he wrote, "It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental." It's this "something," this je ne sais quoi, that gives art and morality their power, their connection to something beyond.

Morality and art, they bind us because we experience them, not with our minds alone, but with a deeper knowing, a noumenal sense.  Literature, with its words that bleed into the soul, is especially potent. As McKean put it, "What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there."

The Germany of now, a fortress nation. Strong. Bound by a blood-forged culture, from the shadow of the Alps in München to the damp stones of Kiel on the Baltic.  From Köln on the Rhine, through the heart of the land, to Dresden, a city carved from stone on the Elbe. A tapestry woven from threads of many tongues and traditions. It's no wonder, then, that this Germany, this entity, sprang not from a single seed but from a confluence of tribes, of bloodlines tangled in the mists of time.

Germania. The name itself, a whisper from the past, a bone thrown to the dogs of history. Its meaning, a battlefield of scholars' ink. Tacitus, that grim chronicler, claimed it hailed from the Tungrians, a tribe that once roamed these lands before the Rhine became their battleground. A name they wore like a shield against the Gauls. Caesar, that ravenous Caesar, first etched "Germanus" into his annals, a word borrowed from the conquered Gauls to separate foe from friend. A distinction drawn in blood. Some say it echoed a word from the Gaulish tongue, a neighbor's name. Caesar himself, in his first chapter on the Gallic Wars, writes of these men, "Germans... who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (the Gauls) are continually waging war... They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles."

Others whisper of a different origin. A spear, the "ger," wielded by these warriors. Or perhaps from the Old Irish "garim," a shout, a challenge, a roar that echoed across the plains. A testament to a people who spoke loud and lived loud. 

Tacitus, in his AD 98 testament, "De Origine et situ Germanorum," paints a picture of a people untouched, unadulterated. "I should regard them (the Germans) as aboriginal," he writes, "and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse." A land they held sacred,  "a wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect." A land that repelled the Romans, those who sought to carve their own empire from the world.

They came to its borders, these Romans, driven by greed for its treasures. They sent out their legions, tasted the land's bounty, but ultimately, the call of Rome was too strong. They returned, leaving the Germanic tribes to their own devices, to the shaping of their own destinies.

The bowl stared back. A dark abyss. Not emptiness, not quite.  Something hung there.  A presence.  Thought, if it could be called that, came and went like desert wind.  A flicker. A sigh.  The artist’s words came back, a whisper now, from years ago.  Frame it.  Simplify.  But the frame wouldn't hold.  The scene pressed in, too much, too much detail.   Picasso, he had his blues. Monet, his greens.  The Italians, a riot of color.  And me?  Me, I was drowning in brown.  This was it.  The start.  The story waiting to be told.  The work.  

Fingertips touched the cold porcelain.  Muscles tensed, a slow tremor running up the arm.  A will to shape, to form.  The water, a mirror, still and deep.  A shiver down the spine.  The brown thing, it resisted.  Stuck like a leech.  More water.  More swirling, more pushing.  Muscles strained, a beat of panic.  A smack.  The handle of the toilet.  A splash.  The water.  The brown thing.

Mop in hand.  Tie choking.  The air thick.  A message left.  A silent scream.  He thought it was art.

More water.  More stillness.  Then the hand reached for the paper.  Wrapped it around itself, a shroud.  A glove.  A second skin.

The hand dipped.  Slow.  Deep.  Like a mother reaching for her child.  But this child was not born of love.  This child was born of need.  Of desperation.

They die behind the wheel. Young ones.  A confluence of things. The kind of fatal vector that lays bare the frailty of youth.  The doctors say the brain ain't full grown. Not ready for the road.  And the road, it chews up the inexperienced. More wrecks. More roll-overs. More speed. More straying from the line.  Kids their age piled in. A known fact. The California people, they did a study.  Linked the age of the passenger to the odds of a wreck. It's a dark math.

They try to hold them back.  Temporary licenses, hours clipped, no young'uns in the back.  But that ain't the answer. The truth is, the young ones, by the numbers, they ain't ready.  Not for the weight of it. Not for the risk.  The doctor Zuckerman, he says eighteen's too young. Says they crave the edge, the rush. The need for speed. It's in their blood.  Let 'em wait.  Let the fire in their belly cool a little. 

Keep 'em off the road. A few more years.  The numbers don't lie. The road's a hungry thing. And soon enough, the next generation will be coming. Millions of them. Ready to drive.

We could teach them.  Driver's ed.  But the wheel, no.  Not till they're older.  Let 'em get some sense in their heads.  Then a permit.  Then the hours behind the wheel.  The same hours every state's got.  California's got six hours behind the wheel and fifty with an adult.  That's the way.  Nationwide.  One law.  One rule for all.

It ain't a new idea.

The Library of Congress, a repository of shadows and dust, held a cache of Edison's early films. Fifteen trick films, fragments of a forgotten time, flickered to life between 1895 and 1901. Illusions, spun from the threads of editing, danced across the screen. My study sought to map the poetics of these phantoms, to trace the ghosts of innovation that haunted their later brethren. 

Mostly, these films were bound to the stage, trapped within the frame of a proscenium. The camera, a watchful eye, remained fixed, unmoving. Long shots and the occasional medium shot, devoid of close-ups, held sway.  A single idea, a single moment, captured in a single shot. The one-shot rule, a strict code, dictated the length, seldom exceeding a minute, a blink in the vast expanse of time.  

The stage's legacy lingered. Figures moved side to side, bound by the proscenium's invisible bars. Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, a film from the year 1900,  offered a stark example. Actors marched in and out, confined to the horizontal axis, the camera unyielding in its gaze.  No pursuit, no movement towards or away.

Like phantoms on a stage, these films existed in a world of artifice. Close-ups, a language of intimacy, were absent. The audience, as in the theater, beheld the whole, framed within the proscenium's embrace.  Narrative, confined by the single shot, was sparse. The films were vaudeville in essence, a series of tricks—magic, disappearances, substitutions— fleeting moments of wonder.

But appearances can be deceiving. One conceptual shot, a single breath of the story, might be a tapestry woven from many threads. Mary, Queen of Scots, a film from 1895, offered a glimpse into this hidden world. The severed head, a phantom image, hinted at the artifice, the joins in the fabric.

John Taylor of Caroline. A man of the soil. A farmer. But not just any farmer. He held fast to a creed, a vision of a republic built on the back of the land, on the sweat of honest labor.  His words, they rang out like a hammer blow, striking at the heart of government, demanding liberty, demanding freedom from the grasping hands of power. His creed, it was born of the earth, of the furrows he plowed, of the harvest he reaped. He saw the government as a blade, sharp and dangerous, capable of cutting away at the very fabric of a free man's life.

He believed the young nation held a promise, a chance to forge a new path, unburdened by the ghosts of old empires. The land, it was a canvas, and the people, the artists. They could paint a picture of self-governance, a nation where the rights of man, like the roots of a mighty oak, stood firm and unshakeable.  He saw these rights as a fragile web, interconnected, each strand dependent on the others.  If one broke, the whole tapestry frayed.

But Taylor knew the darkness within man, the hunger for power, the instinct to dominate.  He spoke of a duality, a battle that raged within every heart, a struggle between good and evil.  He believed a government must be built to withstand this storm, to hold back the tide of corruption.  He sought a government that protected property, that nurtured the land, that kept the wolves of capitalism at bay.

He called for a government of limited scope, bound by the chains of the Constitution, its powers spelled out in black and white.  He saw the danger of a sprawling, bloated government, a beast that consumed all in its path. But a simple reading of the words, he warned, was a dangerous path. The spirit, the intent, it must be understood. He looked to the Declaration of Independence, a testament to the sovereignty of the states, the foundation of their freedom.

The figures, they told a story. Figure Seventeen, it showed a fall off, a sudden drop in those commuter logs come the third month. A kind of dying ember. It was disquietening to see it, hard to say why the fire went out. Winter had come to the New England campus, biting wind and snow. Fewer souls on bikes or on foot, that much was clear. And December, it was the end of the fall term, a time for books and deadlines and the frantic scramble to close out the semester. The log, it might have slipped the mind, lost in the shuffle. Then came the holidays, a season of rushing and feasting, and the campus emptied, folks scattered to their homes. Come January, the spring term began, and still the logs were scant. February, it was a mystery.

The project, it had a life of its own, a quick burst of energy at first, like a flame ignited. Then, the natural pull of the embers, a fading glow. To fight it, they put on a show, a "Carpool Challenge Week" in March, a blaze of prizes and promises. It worked, the logs climbed back up. But the lesson was clear: keeping the fire burning, that's a fight. The holidays, the breaks, the natural ebb and flow of things, they all work against you.

Another thing, people and their cars. Freedom, independence, that's what they crave, woven into the fabric of this land. So carrots, they had to offer carrots. Gift cards here, a massage there, a book, a cup of coffee. It worked, but maybe more could have been done. A bicycle, a sleek hybrid, even a silent electric car, those would have been prizes worth fighting for. Maybe then the logs wouldn't have fallen so low. The prizes, they stayed the same. But what if they grew, a promise of something better, something bigger? A bicycle in December, then a hybrid in January, a whisper of an electric car in February. Maybe then, the fire wouldn't have died.

The Exchange Traded Fund, or ETF, a curious construct. Like an index fund, it seeks to mirror a collection of assets, be it a market index, a commodity, or a basket of securities. Yet it moves with the quickness of a lone stock, traded on the open exchange. It offers the spread of the index, the freedom of a single share. You can sell it short, leverage its rise, buy in fractions. Its cost, a shadow compared to the mutual fund's burden. But there is a price for this agility - a commission for every trade, a toll on the path.  And there are others, whispers of danger. Can the diversification it promises truly hold, or is it a mirage? 

This, then, is the question we grapple with: the ETF IHF. We dissect its heart, its ten biggest holdings, which claim dominion over 63.58% of its assets. Can these ten stand in for the whole? Do they truly capture the essence of the fund, or are they but a flawed reflection?

We examine their influence, their weight in the portfolio's rise and fall, their Beta, their return.  A portfolio built on these ten, we find, would yield a return 6.11% higher than the ETF itself. Its Beta, a measure of volatility, would be lower, a whisper in the storm.

But is this difference real, or a figment of chance? To answer, we delve deeper, measuring the standard deviation of each stock, their inherent risk, and compare it against the ETF's own.

Dream-Land, one of Poe's own pronouncements, a better thing. In it, words like "Thulé," whispered twice, echo back from Virgil. A place north of Britain, a rim of the known world, the Greeks called it. Virgil used it, that's certain. But a shadow falls, a more immediate source. Poe, he was drawn to the dark German tongues.

This much is said in the book, Poe's Politian and Goethe's Mignon, by Karl J. Arndt. The two poems, he sees a kinship, a likeness in their sorrow. Poe, mimicking the German master.

The Oxford Companion speaks of Goethe, his Faust, a play in two parts, the first birthing in 1808, the second in the year of the master's own passing, 1832. Within this second part, a poem, "The King of Thulé." A king, grief-stricken, his queen gone, a goblet her parting gift. He drinks, remembers, and finally, finds his solace in death. The king of Thulé, the king of Poe's dream, shadows entwined, a doppelganger of loss, a crutch of drink.

Faust, translated into play by H.P. Grattan, just a year before Poe's own use of "Thulé" in "The Pit and the Pendulum," 

"Ultima Thule," whispered once in the Pit, but twice in Dream-Land, bookends of the poem. The King of Thulé, Dream-Land, companions on this dark journey. The speaker, he walks through the landscape of Thulé, a land of shades, of ghosts, of a world drained of color. It echoes the king's grief, his loneliness, the slow decay of his will.

Goethe, a titan of language, a name known to Poe, if for no other reason than his admiration for Tennyson.  The master's influence, a whisper in the wind, a touch in the night, a reflection in the mirror of Poe's own soul.

The law in these parts, they call it California, says a man can be made to pay more than just for the harm he's done.  If a man acts with malice.  Say a woman, Jennifer Palmer, slips on a puddle of applesauce in a store, a place they call D&D Markets.  And say the manager, a man named Martin, he's been told twice about the mess, twice!  But he's busy with his supper, he says.  A half-hour passes, the woman falls, breaks her back. Now she wants more than just what the doctor's gonna cost her. She wants to bleed the man dry.  She wants punishment.

The judge, he ain't gonna throw her claim out just like that.  California law says a man can be made to pay more if he acted with a kind of knowing disregard for the harm he might cause.  Despicable, they call it.  Jennifer, she'll say Martin knew the applesauce was a danger, knew folks had been slipping before.  Six times, she'll say, in the year gone by.  And still he didn't clean it up.  

Now, whether his actions were truly despicable, that's a tougher call.  But it's a question for a jury.  And the facts, well, they speak for themselves.  The day of the spill, a young man, Rich Wayne, told Martin about the applesauce.  Martin, he says he's on break, no time for complaints. Then another man, Mary Haddigan, he tells Martin too. Same answer.  Half an hour later, Jennifer Palmer comes along, slips, and falls.  

The question is, did Martin know the applesauce was a danger?  Did he willfully ignore it?  That's what the jury will have to decide.

Four years gone now, a course in Islam taken at CBC.  The air hung thick with the smoke of argument, the question burning bright: Was Islam a religion of violence? It seems a question more urgent now than ever.  The world's eye, since that day in '01, has shifted. From the glare of hostility towards Islam, towards the extremists, to a tolerance bordering on the blind. A man named Barack Obama, a name that might have been met with scorn back then, could now stand for the highest office.  A man with a lineage entwined with the faith.

The Prophet's story, it has a pull. The facts I'd gathered, the history I'd absorbed, painted a different picture. Muhammad, the conqueror, the one who subjugated tribes, forcing them to bend the knee to his God. But the biography, it tells another tale. A man of humility, misunderstood, even. He offered his truth, and men, drawn to its light, came to him.

A shadow falls over the similarities between the ministries. Jesus, the Son of Man, and Muhammad, each with their miracles. A feast multiplied from meager provisions to feed forty. It's a deliberate echo, a striving to cast Muhammad as a prophet of simple truth, needing no grand pronouncements. A fallacy, a cheap trick. It diminishes the miracle of Christ, steals his light. 

The stories, they strive to prove the truth of the faith, the power of conversion.  But they whisper, they relay, they recount tales told through a veil of second, third, and fourth-hand accounts.  The truth fades, obscured, leaving behind a shadow of doubt.

The most troubling thing, the weight that settles in the gut, is the attempt to elevate Muhammad.  A man of gentleness, wisdom, and grace. But history, it tells a different story. A tale of ambition, of conquest. One wonders, if true history were known, would the faith itself be shaken? Would the edifice of belief crumble?

The Word went out, spoken and carried on the wind. But the wind, it shifts. The currents of thought, they turned, leaving the man from Nazareth behind in the dust. Look back, and you’ll see the path of Christ’s flock straying, year by year, further from the shepherd’s fold. This world now, it spins faster, hungers for change, for a new dawn. The old ways cling, a brittle husk, resisting the tide. But the tide, it won’t be denied. 

A remembering will come, a yearning for the bone of truth buried under layers of creed and dogma.  A sifting, a searching.  Decades, maybe centuries, it will take.  But the river runs back to the source.  The clock hands will turn, one by one, stripping away the accretions, leaving bare the stark words of the man who walked the hills of Galilee.  

This wind will blow across the land, from sea to shining sea.  It will gather the faithful, not to a single flock, but to a single understanding.  The church, the institution, it will stand, a weathered sentinel, guiding the way.  Yet the flock will be thinned, the multitude of voices unified in the purity of the original song. 

This is how history bends, how empires rise and fall, how darkness yields to light.  Remember the Romans, who once crushed the Christians beneath their heel? Now they kneel before the very cross they erected. Remember the chains that bound the enslaved, and the day they rose.  

This too, will come to pass.  We must learn to read the scriptures anew, not with the eye of the letter, but with the heart of the spirit.  

For before Jesus came, there was only the echo of the One true God.  There was only the ancient covenant, whispered across the desert sands.  Judaism, the seed from which Christianity sprung.  A faith rooted in the word, in the law, in the unwavering belief in a single, all-powerful God.

The beast of industry it howls. Greed, the marrow in its bones. Man, you see, a creature of want. He builds his towers, his monuments of steel and stone, and in their shadows the world bleeds out. The Jungle, it shows you this. The men who own the gears, the men who pull the strings, they see no soul but their own reflected in the glass of the boardroom. They speak of progress, of wealth, but their words are the smoke that chokes the air, the effluent that poisons the river.  

Sinclair, he paints the picture with words like a man with blood on his hands. "The line of the buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky," he writes. And what a sky it is, choked with the godless breath of a thousand furnaces. The men inside them, they are cogs, their lives measured in the clanging rhythms of the machines. "From the top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds," Sinclair says. No loyalty, no decency, only the hunger for the next dollar, the next profit.

The workers, they are the ground beneath the feet of the beasts. They toil and sweat and bleed, their bodies ground down like the grain they process, their lives a handful of dust in the wind. There are no laws to protect them, no solace in the night. Unions, they promise hope, but offer only another kind of cage. 

The Jungle, it shows the truth. Man's heart, it is a dark and twisted thing. And in the shadow of the factories, he withers and dies, a slave to his own greed.

The telling of a story. It's a matter of weaving a mood, a feeling, around the bone of it. Some men do this better than others. Fitzgerald, he knew this.  He'd take a word, a thing, and pair it with something else, something it don't rightly belong with, and suddenly, you see it in a new light. He did this with colors, too. Gold, green, white, gray, red, pink. He'd stain them with meaning, make them hum with a certain resonance, then he'd fling them back at you, these colors, to remind you of what he wanted you to feel about something. He did it with white and gray, these two sides of the same coin. White, clean, a kind of false purity. Gray, the fading of it all.

He starts laying it down early, this meaning, in this story of Gatsby's. Daisy and Jordan, always in white.  Everyone in white, it seems. Nick in his white flannels, Tom in his white shirt, Catherine powdered white as bone. Even the party, when Nick is trying to get a handle on it, there's a break from the white, a burst of gaudy color. But the white comes back, a constant, a tide.  He sees it in the buildings, the names on a list, even the way the people move through the city. It's everywhere.

Then, when you think you've got it figured out, he takes the white and the gray and he leans in close, and he shows you Daisy. And she's lost in the white again, a ghost in a little white roadster. Not a woman, not really. Just a thing he wants, a white dream. And the gray, it creeps in around her too, a haze of fur, a whisper of forgotten things.  He's making a point, you see. Daisy isn't just a woman. She's a symbol, a reflection of something deeper, something that's already gone.

The sun-scorched earth of San Diego County yields bounty. Tomatoes plump beneath the endless sky, citrus trees groan with fruit, and the land whispers its secrets in the rustle of leafy greens and the scent of ripe squash and the bitter bite of pepper. They say the people here hunger for this earth, for the taste of what grows free from the taint of chemicals. Organic. A word whispered like a prayer in the marketplace, where long lines snake past tables piled high with eggs and milk from contented cows. Farther out, beyond the clamor, the farms stand silent, offering more than just sustenance. There, on these sun-baked acres, you might find a man with calloused hands and eyes that hold the wisdom of the soil, offering tours through the rows of plants and the fields where birds sing their silent songs. This, they say, is the way. A way to feed the soul and the body, to walk the path of the earth and leave it richer for your passing.

But the path is not always easy. The earth demands respect, a constant vigilance against the pests that gnaw and the weeds that choke. The hands that toil are weary, the back aches with the burden of labor. The yields may come smaller, the losses heavier, but the reward lies in the whispers of the wind through the trees, the dance of the butterflies, the symphony of life that blooms in the absence of poison.

This land, this parcel of chaparral and oak woodland, sits heavy with history. It has known the touch of ancient people, the rumble of cattle hooves, the silence of forgotten dreams. It is a place where the whispers of the past mingle with the cries of the present, a tapestry woven from the threads of time. Here, in the shadow of the Cleveland National Forest, the land and the people stand at a crossroads. They say there are programs, whispers of assistance, to help those who choose this path, to help them find balance, to heal the land and themselves. But the burden of choice rests on their shoulders, a heavy weight in the hands of a farmer who seeks both profit and peace.

The land of culture, it ain't a clear path. It's more like a tangled thicket, shadows and sunlight mingling. You can't grasp it whole, can't pin it down.  Sayin' all Russians are stubborn, all Japanese accommodating, that's like trying to paint a whole sky with a single brushstroke. Too broad, too quick. 

You gotta learn the rhythm of the place, the music it plays. How it whispers in the wind, how it echoes in the heart. A man walkin' into a foreign land sees it through the lens of his own, comparisons bloomin' up like weeds. 

Understanding another's way, that's a journey.  You gotta pore over their histories, their scars and their stories. But don't go in to judge or change it. Just breathe it in, feel its weight. Work within its lines, especially if you're standin' at a disadvantage. Out there, respect's your only shield against the unknown.

Culture ain't just about borders, it's a web woven tight.  Even within a nation, companies build their own little worlds.  Some run on long days and hard labor, others on a more leisurely pace.  Look at their clothes, how they speak, who they trust.  It's all there, writ in the lines of their faces, the way they move.

Values, now those are the heart of the matter. They tell you why a culture ticks.  If shame is a heavy weight, a man won't risk it for a deal. If hardship is a badge of honor, he'll fight tooth and nail.

Before you sit at the table, you gotta know these things. But even then, learn the man across from you.  Find the threads that bind, the common ground. That's where the real bargainin' begins.

The fool, he'd say in his heart, "No God."  Psalm 14, the Book of Psalms, says so. And Anselm, the holy man, he built his case on those words.  The same God, the God of the Covenant, is the God that Aquinas spoke of too.  So we'll assume they both knew him, this God, the one from the scriptures. Otherwise, comparing their arguments would be like comparing apples to... well, something else entirely.

Now, both men, they had their points. But neither, not really, gave us a whole picture. A complete grounding for belief.

Take Anselm first.  He looked inward, to the soul. He said, to understand God, you have to look within. For if you can conceive of God, you can't conceive of him not being. It's a tangled path, this one, his words sometimes hard to follow. But the heart of it is this: God is known through the knowing itself. He's within us already. No need for signs or wonders, just the sureness of what we know. Faith, they call it.

Aquinas, he was different.  He sought proof in the world, in the things we can see and touch.  No faith needed, he said, just reason.  Five arguments he laid out, each one a building block. Change, cause, chance, degrees of perfection, and the harmony of the universe.  He said, if you see a puzzle missing a piece, you know it's there, even if you can't see it. The logic of it demands it.

The man they called Buddha was born, somewhere in the shadow of that long ago century, fifth or sixth. A prince, he cast aside the world, sought the silence within. His words took root and grew, flowering into the faith of Buddhism, a tendril of which was known as Theravada. Five hundred years have turned since his passing, and the tendrils have stretched, taken on new forms. In Sri Lanka, where the Theravada roots run deep, they hold a ceremony, cutting water. Monks and the lay folk alike gather, a ritual born not of Buddha's own hand but of time and change. The differences, they run deep, from the surface of things to the heart of the matter. Both monk and layman, bound by the faith, have had to shift, to bend the ancient doctrines to the wind. Forces, both dark and light, have pressed upon them.

There are words we'll be using, words to guide us through this tangled wood. Internal, external. The internal is born of the followers of the Buddha's path, whether robed or not. The external, from those who walk a different road. Hostile, a force that seeks to wound the faith, to twist and break its branches. Benign, a force that means neither harm nor good, but which may bring one or the other in its wake. These words, they will echo through these pages.

First, let us speak of the core. The doctrines that bind the Theravada heart. They seek refuge in the triple gem: the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Sangha. The Dhamma, it is the Tripitaka, the three baskets of wisdom. Suttas, Vinaya, Abhidhamma. The Suttas, the words of the Buddha. The Vinaya, the rules of conduct, the path laid out for both monk and layman. The Abhidhamma, the metaphysics, the nature of being. The teachings of no-self, of suffering, of impermanence. These are the truths that bind and break the wheel of Samsara, the endless turning of birth and death. Desire, hatred, delusion, all fade when the light of enlightenment breaks through. In the Vinaya, the rules are laid out, five for the layman, a shield against harm: no killing, no lying, no stealing, no unchastity, no intoxication. For the monk, the path is longer, the rules more intricate. But at the heart, the four noble truths remain: the truth of suffering, the truth of its cause, the truth of its cessation, the truth of the path that leads to it.

The two nations, the United States and Mexico, were once bound by a rivalry that stretched like a long, lean shadow, fifty-seven years from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts, 2000, p. 145). The high tide of this animosity crested in the Mexican-American War, a conflict of 1846-1848 where the United States, in a swift and brutal reckoning, subdued Mexico. Texas and the Southwest fell into American hands, wounds fresh and festering.  

But this was only the storm's eye. Smaller skirmishes, like brush fires, flared between the two nations, finally dying down in the hushed stillness before the First World War.  The roots of their discord ran deep, tangled in religion, culture, and the tangled web of material interests. (Schmitt, 1974, p. 30-31).

This dance of rivalry is not unfamiliar. Nations that share a border, their fates intertwined, often find themselves locked in a struggle for dominance, a tug-of-war over land and resources.  The United States and Mexico are but one example among many.  David M. Pletcher (1977) wrote, "Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting, overarching American diplomatic problems" (p. 41). Both nations, geographically close, have stood in opposition to American expansion, while others in Latin America have found more fertile ground for cooperation.

Religion, a potent and divisive force, also cast a dark shadow over their relationship. Sally Frahm (2001) points out, "if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy" (p. 86). Like the Cold War, a battle fought not just on battlefields but in the minds of men, the rivalry between the United States and Mexico was fueled by a clash of ideologies, albeit ones rooted in faith, not politics.  This distrust, inherited from the old empires, the English and the Spanish, proved a formidable barrier to any hope of lasting peace.

Diehl and Goerts (2000) catalogued seventeen disputes between the two nations during that fifty-seven year period. Most were skirmishes over territory, border raids, and the ever-present threat of violence at the frontier.  Bandits and outlaws, like wolves on the prowl, preyed on both sides of the border, their presence a constant reminder of the volatile tension. (Schmitt, 1974, p. 97).

Schmitt (1974) suggests that the rivalry began to wane as Mexico, caught in the grip of need, leaned heavily on the United States for support.  (p. 109)  In the dying embers of the nineteenth century, American ambitions shifted from territorial conquest to a more insidious form of control: economic intervention in Mexico. (p. 110).

Fifteen years gone now.  A sudden sickness, a fate unseen. It took hold like a fever, stole my strength, left me hollowed out. A nurse I was, back then. The steady work, the comfort of the sickbed, a shield against the ghosts of a childhood too harsh. "Always a need," they'd say, "for hands that mend. People will always be broken." So I built my life on that promise.  Science, journalism, those were the dreams, buried deep. But the need was stronger.

Forty-six years, alone, with nothing but dust in the bank. The years crawl on, fifteen of them, stretched thin on a government's meager grace. My own, I own nothing.  A hand-to-mouth existence, each day a battle against the gnawing fear, the hollow ache of what might have been. Nothing certain but the cold grip of need. Yet through it all, a truth remains. Family, friends, a lifeline thrown.  They held me steady when the world spun. And believe this, in the face of true ruin, you find out just how empty your strength is.

Life, it throws its storms. Big and small, they come without warning. No map, no guide.  We can preach preparedness, build our bunkers, but some things are too vast, too cruel.

They say we must cut our ties with the government, its ship run aground.  But what good is a lone island when the sea is rising?  I say, let us learn to trust again, to build bridges, to share the burden. Our forefathers, they didn't conquer hardship alone. It was compassion, respect, the sharing of what little they had that saw them through. The wagons trains, they rolled westward on shared hope, not rugged defiance.

Be ready, yes, I am.  Water purification, canned goods, a first-aid kit, the tools to weather the storm.   A wood stove, a garden if you have the land. But alongside these things,  reach out. Know your neighbor, their story, their struggles. For in the end, it is the bonds we weave that will endure.

The question of form, of how life takes shape, has haunted the minds of men since time immemorial.  Why do these creatures twist and turn, these shells, these bones, into the patterns they do? Are there invisible threads guiding them, unseen constraints upon their becoming?  Even now, the naturalist barely scratches the surface, struggling to capture the essence of creation in the cold logic of numbers.  Yet men have tried.  They have sought to quantify the dance of the whorls, to map the spiral path of growth in these mollusk shells, these Prunum.  

They speak of mathematical models, of software that can conjure forms, and they delve into the past, tracing the lineage of these shells through the eons. They peer into the heart of the shell, the columella, that central thread through which the whorls unfurl.  They count the turns, the sutures that bind them, the aperture that breathes life into the empty form.  And they seek to understand, to unravel the mystery of how these silent creatures, these Prunum, have shaped themselves through the endless passage of time. 

They speak of the shell as a journey, a pilgrimage through space and time, a spiral path etched into the fabric of existence.  They see the apex, the starting point, the base where it rests.  They trace the path of the aperture, the opening through which life itself emerges.  They try to capture the essence of this journey, to translate it into language the mind can grasp.  

And perhaps, just perhaps, they will find the answer.

The death of infants and newborns in this land of Java and Sumatra, it has hung steady these last ten years.  The country aims for the promised moons of those Millennium Declarations, clean water and the like, but the children and their mothers, they fall short.  The reasons for this failing are many, and lie not in the programs themselves, but in the bones of the system.

They boast of births attended by learned hands, 72% they say, but these hands are not always of the doctor. Midwives, women of the village, they attend, but no knife to staunch a hemorrhage, no scales to weigh the fading life.  So the mothers bleed out, a silent toll.

The children, too, they suffer.  Diarrhea, a scourge of the young, treated less and less by those with skill.  And the care after birth, a shadow, a whisper, lacking for the mother and child alike.

The steel cuts, the cesarean, a rare thing here.  4% maybe, a whisper compared to the cities where it's 7%.  The knife, a luxury for the city dweller, a phantom for the farmer.  And the poor, they are forgotten, the line between rich and poor a chasm.  27%, they say, the difference in care.  The cost of healing, a wall too high for them to climb.

So what then, the question hangs, a shroud over the land.  Programs, they offer, quick fixes, but at what cost?  One hand reaches for the child, the other forgets the mother.  Resources diverted, like ants swarming a dropped crumb, leaving the rest to wither.

The Victorian age, a time of suffocating detail and endless pronouncements on the station of the titled. Yet even in that gilded cage, shadows stirred.  Two novels, *Oliver Twist* and *Wuthering Heights*, claw at the edges of this tradition, venturing into the realm of the uncanny. Both weave a tapestry of mystery, a hint of the perverse, a dissonance that resonates through the characters, illuminating their motives, their buried grief.  

Consider this passage from Dickens: 

>“And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, … he found that he was talking to them…. Suddenly he started back at the report of fire arms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which weared and tormented him incessantly.” (Dickens, 220)

A fever dream, a descent into chaos. These novels, they use this disquiet often, in dreams, in visions, though the purpose shifts with each turn. In *Oliver Twist*, these phantoms delve into the boy's own wounded soul, revealing the ache within, the recognition of a world turned cruel. When the shooting finally returns, in chapter 28, it's a reliving, a reenactment, as if through a fogged glass.  He seeks help, but the world spins, the hand of fate a cold, unseen thing.  The senses are numb, the pain a constant ache, a companion to the fear.  Whose will brought this down upon him? Not his own, not in this maelstrom. A sense of defeat creeps in, a hardening of the spirit, as if Fagin's darkness has begun to seep into him, a poison that numbs the will to resist.

And again, from *Wuthering Heights*:

>“The day passed off – day! There was no day; it was gone as soon as come – and night came on again; night so long, and yet so short; long in it’s dreadful silence and short in it’s fleeting ours.”

Two years back I was working the after-school shift, tutoring the small ones. English and reading, that's where my own light shone brightest. They sent me a boy named Adrian. Third or fourth grade, maybe. Trouble reading, he was.  Something off about it, the way he struggled. Some letters, clear as day. Others, not a lick of sense. Like a broken clock, telling different times.  He spoke English right good, this boy, though. Latino, that much was plain. 

Then came the day I was left holding the fort while the rest of the kids were gone on some outing. Adrian's mother walked in. Not a word of English passed her lips, just Spanish. My own Spanish, well, it was threadbare, a learner's tongue. But we managed. Then it hit me, like a stone dropped from a height. Adrian, he could read fine. It was just the alphabet he didn't know.  English letters, strange to him. Don't know if it helped much, but I hope the boy's doing better now. 

I tell this story, because the language gap in these schools, it's a damn canyon.  Especially here in California. And it ain't always so clear cut. A kid speaking English perfect might still struggle. Reading, it can be a hard birth. 

Adrian, his problem was simple:  English reading, the alphabet, the sounds.  But for the kids barely speaking English, it's a heavier load. No single answer, no magic bullet. Dual language, immersion, private tutors, ESL classes - none of it solves it alone.  It takes everything, all mixed together.

Dual language, it ain't just for Spanish speakers. For all the kids. They say it's a waste, that it won't help the majority. Lies. Make it the rule, not the exception, and everyone benefits. But how? Every teacher bilingual? Unrealistic.  But maybe, just maybe, some helpers, aides, whatever you call 'em, who speak both tongues.

The world tells you from the start there's somethin' bigger. Somethin' vast. Unreckonable. They send you to pews or temples or they tell you to find it in the dark corners of your own skull. Most swallow it whole, the stories passed down like worn rosary beads. But some, they spit it out.  Say there's nothin' but the skin of your own world.  They build their own gods, their own cages.  And the path? It twists and turns, searchin' for some light in the goddamn dark. 

"A cardinal," my pa said, when I asked him what bird he liked best. We were on the porch, rain drummin' on the tin roof, stink of wet earth and smoke in the air.  He was lookin' out at the water runnin' from the gutters, drownin' the plants.  His eyes, they were lost, half-rememberin', half-searchin'.  He'd thinned out, his clothes hangin' like rags.  Hair scraggly, like the last tendrils of a winter storm. He didn't look at me. Couldn't.  I felt it, the lonesome pull, the fear. Couldn't speak it, not out loud.  'Cause sayin' it would make it real. So I hugged him, pulled my chair closer, and watched the rain with him, the sky bleedin' purple and gray.

He died in December, five days after my twenty-second year.  Chemo and radiation, they kept him breathin', but nothin' eased the burnin'.  A few more months, they said.  What good that was, I couldn't say.  What kind of God would do that?  Layin' there in the dark, no prayers came. If He was listenin', He stopped a long time ago.

Didn't want to watch him go.  Didn't want to see the light fade from his eyes.  Wanted to hold him in the way he was, not the way he wasn't.  Knew him better than anyone else.  He wouldn't have wanted me there, watchin' the end.  Curled up tight in my bed, waitin' for the news.

They didn't call.

The Gothic, a name that sings of contradiction, an oxymoron for "Old-New" as Watt declared. Praised and damned, mocked and lauded for its glimpse of the terrible sublime -  a dance with darkness. Walpole, he who birthed the beast with his *Castle of Otranto*, wove threads of ancient romance and the newfangled novel. An echo of the stage, a mimicry of nature, a "Gothic Story," he called it.  He drew upon the bones of Gothic theatre, its architecture, its lore. A tattered word, "Gothic," flung against epochs and peoples, marked archaic, unsophisticated. Yet, in its shadow, a new light flickered. The intimacy of the novel, the peering into the soul of man, gave the Gothic a strange life, a timeless resonance. 

And from the ashes of chivalry arose a specter. The medieval knight, brave, honorable, competent, a fading ideal in the eyes of the writers, especially Walpole. They saw a world gone soft, a world lacking the steel of the past. Chivalry, they held, was the cure, a balm for the wounds of modernity.  The "gothic past" shimmered, romanticized, a promise of what might have been. Walpole, caught in the maelstrom of politics, a man unjustly accused, saw this decay. Did he yearn for a simpler time, for the supposed virtue of a bygone age? 

Frederic, his prince, a figure sculpted from chivalric dreams. He was a prince, yes, marked by suffering, touched by tragedy. "Gallant," "courteous," a knight raised to an impossible height, a trope echoing through the ages. An exaggeration, a hint of the Gothic excess to come.

The movement of goods, a river of commerce, flows from the customer's want to the raw earth itself. From there it spills through the channels of supply, production, and distribution, finally reaching the waiting hands of its maker. This river, this chain, was given its name in the year of '82 by a man named Keith Oliver, a consultant who saw the need for order in the chaos. He spoke of planning, of wielding control over this flow, of making it swift and sure, all to satisfy the hunger of the customer.  

Six pillars hold this chain aloft. Production, supply, the hoard of inventory, the choice of place, the rumble of transport, and the whispers of information.  These are the tools the manager wields, shaping the river to serve the needs of the consumer.

Production, the first and most vital link. Here the ground is broken, the earth yielded. It is the heart of the chain, beating with the rhythm of want and need. The manager must know what the customer desires, what whispers on the wind of the marketplace. The market, a vast and shifting sea, holds the answers. Through its currents, the manager discerns the demands, the call for this or that.  Then comes the decision: what shall be made, and in what quantity? The manager, with a keen eye, chooses the place of creation, the factory that will best serve both volume and quality, the place where the river will flow truest.  Finally, the manager sets the pace of work, the maintenance of the machinery, for every detail here is etched in stone, every misstep a cost in time and coin. For I have seen the wheels grind to a halt, the river choked, in the face of carelessness.

Supply, the second pillar. It speaks of strategy, of forging alliances and choosing partners. A single product may have many faces, many divisions, each with its own tools, its own workers, its own mastery. The manager must decide where each piece fits, where each thread is woven. And sometimes, the manager chooses to yield, to outsource, to let another hand shape the clay. This is done for velocity, for the swiftness with which goods are made and delivered, for the flexibility to adapt, and for the ever-present need to keep the cost low, the river flowing clear.

The sign, a scrap of cardboard held aloft, spoke of things best left unsaid.  "Hitler is alive in Burma," it declared in a scrawling hand, the ink bleeding into the fibers like a dying man's blood.  Ellen Page, face pale and drawn under the harsh glare of the streetlamps, stood alone.  

Burma. A place name that tasted of dust and sorrow. A land ruled by men with iron fists and eyes as black as the crows that circled above the jade-green rice paddies. A junta, they called them, these men who seized power in a whirlwind of bullets and betrayal. Since '62, the year the world shifted on its axis, Burma had been a country choked by silence. Until the Saffron Revolution. Monks, their robes the color of dying embers, rose up, their chanting a challenge to the storm clouds gathering over the land.  

The government, a viper coiled in its own poison, allowed the protests at first, a cruel amusement. But the whispers grew louder, the crowds swelled. The viper struck. Monasteries, havens of peace, were overrun, their sacred halls echoing with the cries of the fallen. Foreign eyes, seeking the truth, were dragged into the darkness, their lenses forever capturing the horror. Kenji Nagai, a man who dared to witness, paid the ultimate price. 

One thousand, they said. Three thousand, whispered the wind. But the Colonel, a shadow escaping the viper's coils, spoke of a number too terrible to utter. 

This, this was not new. The hunger for power, the thirst for control, it was a disease that festered in the heart of men. The Caesars, draped in their purple robes, claimed to be chosen by the gods, their will absolute. The emperors of Japan, shrouded in myth and whispered prayers, believed themselves divine. And here, in the land of the free, a man named Bush, his face a mask of piety, sought counsel from a man called Haggard, a shepherd of souls steeped in the darkness of the abyss.  

Tiananmen Square, a sea of humanity yearning for freedom, met with the cold steel of tanks. June 4th, a date etched in blood. The official count, a lie whispered by the wind. In Rwanda, the jungle ran red with the blood of innocents, the cries of the slaughtered swallowed by the silence of the world. And the Third Reich, a testament to the depths of human depravity, where the stench of death lingered long after the ashes had settled.  

The world, a tapestry woven with threads of light and darkness, turned its gaze away. But the truth, like a wound that never heals, remained.

Duke Ellington. A name that hangs heavy in the air of jazz. His legacy's woven from the thread of years, spun long and taut. It's in the shaping of his orchestra, his hand upon the keys a whisper, a guide. His compositions, they breathe with a richness, a complexity, showcasing the bones and sinew of each man in the band.  

He built a framework, a cage of sound where souls could soar, improvise.  Tightly woven phrases, orchestrated, demanding the particular grace of each player, each note a brushstroke on a canvas of sound.  He coaxed the tone of the whole, birthing something new, something singular. A testament to the music itself.

The Grove, that book of hushed pronouncements, speaks of Ellington's sound, his daring. "Creole Love Call," they say, using the voice as an instrument. A threadbare blues, twelve bars, six choruses, each one a different shade of the same sorrow. The voice, it starts smooth, a lover's caress, then rasps, a plea from the abyss. The trumpet, muted, a sigh, a lament, reaching for notes beyond the ordinary. The clarinet, a cry, soaring, lost in a sea of syncopated piano. The brass, the reeds, they echo, they answer.  A crescendo, a final chorus, a voice now a growl, a beast unleashed. A trombone, a final discordant wail, a question unanswered.

And the voice, always the voice. A color, a texture, a thing apart. A tool, a weapon, a mirror held up to the soul. This is Ellington's voice, his touch, his lasting legacy. In "Hot and Bothered," the trumpet and the scat, a conversation in tongues. A dance between instrument and voice, each borrowing from the other, a tapestry of sound. And in "It Don't Mean a Thing," the trombone, a mournful cry, introducing the melody, a single voice in a wilderness of sound.

The need had always been there. A gnawing, unfillable thing. It began when she was fourteen, a girl on the cusp, and had followed her into the hollow of seventeen. Now she knew it wasn't a thing she craved, but someone. Yet no boy had stirred within her the faintest flicker of interest. Some had tried, stumbling through the clumsy rites of courtship, but they were all strangers, passing shadows.  She questioned herself often, this emptiness a vast and echoing canyon of her own making. Theories formed and dissolved like mist. Nothing concrete, nothing that could satiate the ache. So she lived, adrift in a sea of unanswered questions.

Days at home were usually quiet. Her parents, good people, lived in a rhythm of gentle calm. Their words were seldom sharp, their voices never raised. They argued, rarely, only over her insistence on charting her own course, her vibrant spirit a counterpoint to their measured lives. She was their daughter, yet she was a storm in their stillness, a bright flame in their quiet hearth.

But today, the air hung thick and heavy. As she wandered, searching for inspiration, a cry tore through the stillness. Her mother's voice, thin and sharp as broken glass. Panic seized her. "Mom? What is it?"

She found her mother sprawled on the kitchen floor, her face etched with pain. "Ow," she gasped, each word a shard of agony. 

Her daughter knelt beside her, a hand trembling on her mother's arm. "Sweetheart, I need you to take me to the hospital." The words were squeezed out, each syllable a battle.

"Okay, Mom," she said, her voice tight. "Where should I meet you?"

Her mother pointed, her hand trembling. Relief washed over her daughter, gratitude for the strength she had built. She lifted her mother, careful, sure, and carried her to the car. 

The hospital smelled of antiseptic and fear. But fear was a distant whisper compared to the urgency that pulsed through her. She carried her mother inside, her voice a desperate plea for help. 

Doctors materialized, faces creased with concern. A gurney appeared, a silent promise of care. They took her mother away, leaving her daughter adrift in a sea of worry.

The truth, when it came, was simple. A stepping stool, a vase too high, a moment of clumsy grace. It could have been worse.

This study, a reckoning with the ways of heart and blood, sought to prove the claim: that a life lived by the tenets of the Mediterranean Diet, as measured by a score given to the adherence, the so-called 'alternate Mediterranean' or aMed score, would stave off the cruel grip of chronic heart disease and the sudden stroke. This aMed way, a variant of the older Mediterranean ways, calls for the bounty of the earth: plants in their fullness, proteins from the soil and the tree, fat from the olive and the nut, fish from the deep. It calls for a measured hand with animal flesh and the fats that clog the vessels. And it allows, sparingly, for the comfort of wine.

Old studies, like whispers in the wind, had spoken of a link between the Mediterranean way and a lessening of heart's peril, both in life and in death. One trial, a controlled test of will, showed the Mediterranean way more potent than a diet of meagerness in shedding weight and clearing the blood's pathways. But these whispers had not addressed the specter of stroke, nor the shadow of its passing.

This study, a vigil over seventy-four thousand women, their years between thirty-eight and sixty-three, followed them through two decades, from 1984 to 2004. These women, nurses in the service of health, were part of a larger cohort, a thousand souls strong, scattered across eleven states. Six times, the researchers measured their adherence to the aMed ways through written accounts of their meals, these 'food frequency questionnaires' or FFQs. Over ninety-five percent of these women kept to their pact, their records a testament to their commitment. These accounts, scrutinized and tested, were cross-referenced with the cold records of hospitals and death certificates, seeking truth in the face of mortality.

The researchers, seeking to banish the ghosts of chance, averaged the aMed scores, smoothing out the peaks and valleys of individual variation. They adjusted for the shadows that could skew the results: age, the habit of smoke, the weight of the body, the state of womanhood, the use of hormones, the intake of vitamins, the solace of wine, the rhythm of physical activity, and the shield of aspirin.

Then, with the tools of statistics, they measured the link between the aMed score and the risk of heart disease and stroke, using separate models to dissect the fatal and the non-fatal.

The findings were clear: those who lived closer to the aMed ways, with higher scores, faced a lower risk of these afflictions.  Over twenty years, the researchers catalogued a thousand deaths from heart disease, a thousand strokes, and over a thousand deaths from these combined evils. The women at the pinnacle of the aMed scale stood a third less likely to suffer these fates compared to those at the bottom.

The year was two thousand and seven. The bones of the American dream had begun to rattle. A sickness had taken hold, spreading through the veins of the nation. Banks, bloated and gorged on easy credit, stood stripped bare. Houses, once symbols of prosperity, now stood vacant, monuments to a folly. The weight of debt, a shroud, settled upon the land.

They say it was a storm brewing for years. The whispers began in the Clinton years, when the promise of easy money and a second term twisted the hand of policy. Lending was loosened, a reckless act that loosened the very fabric of the financial system. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, twin pillars of the housing market, were pressured to repackage these risky loans, churning them into securities and selling them off like poisoned fruit.

The market, drunk on greed, swallowed them whole. But the hangover came swift and brutal. When the piper demanded payment, the borrowers were gone, vanished like smoke in the wind. The banks, hollowed out, had no cushion, no backstop. The rot spread, consuming the very heart of the economy. Lehman Brothers, a titan of finance, crumbled to dust. Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch were sold off in fire sales. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, their faces pallid with fear, were forced to bend the knee to the government.

The scars remain. A generation scarred by a crisis born of hubris and avarice. And the question lingers, a bitter taste in the mouth: What lessons were learned? Were any? Or will we, like moths to a flame, be drawn to the same folly once more?

Ah, exposition. The place in the telling where the writer stretches his wings, or maybe just flaps them a while before the wind catches him up and carries him away. Or  maybe he just falls out of the sky.  Dr. Merlin, she's been known to let out a howl at the screen when she finds herself drowning in too much of the telling. Not the good kind of drowning, neither.

Exposition ain't your friend.

They say, show, don't tell. But Dr. Merlin, she still stumbles into these long stretches of words where nothin' happens, or worse, too much. Like a hound dog baying at the moon. Exposition, it's that devil on your shoulder whispering to get it all out in the open, get the past laid bare, before you get to the good parts. Don't get me wrong, the other devil whispers too, the one urging you to lay out every detail of every life, every scar and every dream.

Exposition, it's the author doing the telling. Like a sailor reciting a long ballad, the old mariners' tale, pouring out the whole damn history. In a story, it's the author's voice that drowns you in it.

Take for instance, a story you're reading. You're told the heroine met her man, they wed with a flourish, and then he's gone, murdered right before her eyes. You ain't gonna want to read two pages of that, are you? Two whole pages of telling, with nothin' but two lines of dialogue from each character.

You want to see the husband, feel him, hear his words, see the love in his eyes. You want to see how the heroine changes when he comes into her life, how she blossoms under his gaze.  Show me the man, show me the woman, and then show me the tragedy.

Give me meat on the bone, that's what I'm saying. Show me the man, show me the woman, and show me the bone they're both hung on.

There's a temptation to rush past things. You got a new character, maybe he was in the Air Force, now he pumps gas at night, twice-married, no kids, fishes on weekends. He dreams of owning the station someday. Ate Eggs Benedict for breakfast. That's a whole life right there, but you gotta show me, don't just tell me.

The flickering screen coughed up two dispatches from Columbus. First, NBC 4, their faces pale and strained, spoke of a man named Shad Hostettler, a shadow cast in a mug shot, and his deeds in Ashley. A wife, nameless, stabbed multiple times. Two minutes, maybe, before they moved on. Evil, plain as day in his eyes. 

Then, a whisper of a story. Travis Buyers, eighteen, shot in the woods. No arrests, no names. The SWAT Team prowled. The briefness of it stung.  Black boy, shot down. A familiar ache. They don't linger on these things, not like the white boy missing, the white girl snatched.  

The Med-Flight chopper, a hole in its side, a .22 rifle bullet. A whisper of five thousand dollars for whispers. 

Thunder promised, the weekend hot. A tease.  

A robbery, a UDF on Clime Road. A man, dark-skinned, a hoodie pulled low. Six feet, a hundred and fifty pounds.  They lingered on the darkness of his skin, a stain.

Rene Rodriguez, a name from Texas, a kingpin of weed.  Three hundred months they said. Not twenty-five years, no. Three hundred.  Hispanic, they added, though the words felt misplaced.

The tie between brothers. It's a thing woven deep, unyielding. A tangled skein of feeling: love, pride, envy, the dark blood of malice. They know each other like the lines on their own hand. See themselves looking back, a ghost in the mirror. This bond it shows its face in the dark, in the teeth of the storm. Good or bad.  The price you pay for knowing these things, the weight of it all, that's the burden. To see your own face in your brother's eyes, not the mask you show the world, but the raw truth, the bone beneath.
